Game.MiscDetails: Push "Forward Pass" to start each play.

This game does NOT use all of these controls. It has dipswitch settings which allow the games to be controlled with a 360 degree wheel, a 270 degree wheel, a 270 degree digital wheel (using a d2a conveter) and a plain old 8-way joystick with buttons. Uses with steering wheels please note that the game defaults to joystick input. Also note that the pedals optionally can be set to analog mode, but mame disables this feature due to input limitations.
Hold down "Fire" and release for a "Power Blast" attack.
Press both buttons simultaneously to "Loop"
Press both buttons simultaneously to "Loop"
Hold down "Shoot" and release for a "Charge Attack"
Hold down "Shoot" and release for a "Homing Attack"
Press both buttons simultaneously for a "Fatal Attack"
The 2-way horizontal stick is a trigger stick, pushing left rotates the plane anticlockwise, pushing right rotates the plane clockwise
Hold down Fire button to increase power
Pressing bomb button drops bomb and plane also loops. There are no labels on the CP.
A - Power-up B - Hit/Throw C - Unknown action during game

Game.GameName: Air Buster: Trouble Specialty Raid Unit (World)
Game.MiscDetails: Only 1 button on the CP but Mame has 2 mapped (both doing the same thing)
Pinout shows 3 buttons (Fire1, Fire2, Fire3), the flyer shows 2 buttons, Mame has 4 buttons mapped and only 2 seem to work
Button 2 acts differently based on the position on the screen. In the lower half of the screen button 2 will shoot diagonally down to the ground. In the top half it will drop a bomb

Game.GameName: Alex Kidd: The Lost Stars (set 2, unprotected)
Game.MiscDetails: I cold not find what the 3rd button did nor did I immediately notice where it is written in the driver (I think it's one of those generic drivers)
Drop is not the button label (couldn't find one). It drops something behind your character which blocks the path of the Captain Thief which allows you to get away
The default dipswitch is two player mode; you need to F2 into the game's service mode and change it to three player mode to play with 3 players. Each character has special moves.
There isn't much info about the 'real' name for the second button on the guns. If you have any info feel free to corect.
The Joystick controls the player movement. The Kicker is for kicking and passing.

This game uses a dedicated platform shaped like a pair of skiis. It basically acts like a giant analog stick. The player navigates via three, lighted, navigational buttons. (Left, Right and Decision) The Decision button also changes view during gameplay. The 'sweep' and 'edge' descriptions were taken directly from the game's cryptic i/o test menu. Knowing nothing about skiiing, the way the terms 'sweep' and 'edge' were used may be incorrect.

The cpo depicted a simple arrow pointing up for the button label. Upon research I found that this button makes you go down the hill faster. I modified the caption accordingly to avoid confusion. For left and right, the cpo shows a picture of a skiier going left and right respectively. I added the 'ski' part of the caption to prepare for the upcoming icon support in the viewer. As the game doesn't have a true caption, this shouldn't be any less accurate.
To play, aim with the trackball, press the 'lock' button to set the position and then roll to throw.
Left joy controls the left kid, right controls the right kid
Not sure if the label is correct but that's what it does. Couldn't find a pic of the panel
In mame a dial is also emulated. This dial has no apparent function and isn't used in the game at all. It could be reminants of a hack or something.
You can choose at the start of the game whether you would like to use 1 or 2 buttons Type A - 2 buttons Type B - 1 button No pic available, labelled on what they do

The control panel for this game had two pass buttons, but they were merely wired to the same input as only one pass is wired in the schematics. The controls actually used 49-way joysticks for this game, which can be thought of as corse analog sticks.

As with many of the lightgun games at the time, Area 51 requires you to fire off screen to reload. Mame has hacked this to where you fire at the absolute edge of the screen to reload. This is good for people who don't use lightguns but very bad for those of us who do.
Shoot off screen to Reload.
Fire button shoots flying objects, the laser hits the ground units
To change direction hold the direction button down while using the joystick
Sirp Please fix me.... vertical 2 ways have the wrong labels showing up and there isn't a directional 2 way button (vertical), which is what I use.
This Game only uses 3 directions of the 4 way stick. Down is not used.
Button 3 is mapped in driver armedf.c but isn't used
Something of note is this game is pretty much unplayable in Mame without the artwork pack that goes with the rom. Be sure to download it.
I think a bit of how to play info might be necessary. The sawhorse button releases a police barrier to crash cars. The 2nd gear button makes you go faster, but only while it is held.

Mame-wise, this game is really odd. The original game uses dual 4-way trigger sticks. However the author of the mame driver also hacked in an optional 1 stick control scheme so you can play the game with a regular single stick. Unfortunately, this hack interferes with the real inputs so you have to clear one or the other to play properly. It should also be noted that you can not rapid roll with the hack as the game requires you to press both sticks left or right at once to do a roll. Also there is a phantom button defined that is useless. Gameplay Tips: To rapid roll push both sticks in the same direction. (Left or right only) To launch a grenade push both sticks to the outside and fire when ready.
Watch the attract screen to view general and special moves
Don't think Star Trek when you see the warp button. It activates a 10 second time warp which slows the enemies down. So who ever said that Binx was innovative was about 20 years too late.

There are 4 plays (well, four offense, four defense) per player displayed as part of the control panel with an LED for each play and selected with the action button. You cannot play against the computer: this game has to be played with two players. There is a four player version with four trackballs; that version has to be played with 4 players. **Update** I looked in the mame cpo pack and found a pic to fill in the button label. Rebel, if you need a copy of the cpo pack please contact me, it's very helpful.

Label.Name: P1_BUTTON1
Label.Value: Play Select: Press to Pass / Kick

Game.MiscDetails: If a falling block has one block flashing you can press the second button and you get four choices. One of these it to get to select what the next shape will be. Mame has this as a 8-way in the system16.c driver but while playing acts like a 4-way
Special sends out remote attack drones
Button A - Punch Button B - Kick
Button A - Fire Button B - Jump
Holding down attack while standing still will charge up a super punch. Pressing jump and attack at once will do a super kick at the expense of some of your energy.
This will display in mame as a 4 player even though it is only 2 player.
All buttons do the same thing
Panel had directional buttons but of course mame is mapped to the normal joystick inputs
Mame has the original directional buttons mapped to the normal mame movement buttons Buttons are used to select skill level
On the real machine this game had the start button wired onto the action button and the true caption reads 'Start, Shoot & Jump' However it appears that the start button has been split out in mame.

At the ship select screen: To select a 'main shot power type' fighter, select your ship with A button, To select a 'Bomber power type', select your ship with B button, To select a 'Side shot power type', select your ship with C button, To select a 'Speed up type', select your ship with Start button. During game A - Shoot, B - Bomb
Should be just a horizontal 2-way joystick as shown on the coinop link. However mame driver marineb.c has as 8-way
This game uses a one of a kind periscope control and you look into the periscope to see the screen similar to battlezone. For all intensive purposes it's a glorified star wars yoke though.
This game is either set to 2 player, where you can select your toad, or 3 player, where the toads are hard-wired to the panel. You can adjust this setting in the dipswitches.
Both handles have holes for a trigger switch, but generally only one has a button.
Jump - player jumps to the adjacent block in the desired direction Big Jump - plyers jumps over the adjacent block and lands on the next

This game uses a musical 'keyboard' and Turntable. The keyboard is actually 5 trivia buttons rotated 90 degrees, arranged like a section of a piano. Important NOTE: This game has a 6th button next to the start buttons on the control panel labeled 'Effector'. The button is mapped to start3 in mame because of it's physical position and this seems to make the most sense. As the button doesn't really impact gameplay, we'll simply ignore it for now.

This game uses a musical 'keyboard' and Turntable. The keyboard is actually 5 trivia buttons rotated 90 degrees, arranged like a section of a piano. Important NOTE: This game has a 6th button next to the start buttons on the control panel labeled 'Effector'. The button is mapped to start3 in mame because of it's physical position and this seems to make the most sense. As the button doesn't really impact gameplay, we'll simply ignore it for now.
